Color TV wasn't just as simple as adding colored phosphors. That concept is pretty straightforward, and easy to do. The hard part was the shadow mask. You need a way for that electron beam to individually address each of those phosphors, not an easy thing to do. So what they did was use three separate electron beams and put a sheet with thousands of tiny little holes right before the phosphors. This "shadow mask" will prevent the wrong beam from hitting the wrong phosphor. Each beam hits a given hole from a different angle, thus preventing the beam from illuminating the incorrect phosphor.



But making all those tiny holes, not easy. Ok, I guess the holes aren't the hard part really, but the making spaces between the holes smaller. Early shadow masks were so bad at this that you needed to have an insanely powerful electron beam to produce as much light as possible to squeeze through those holes. And even then, color TVs were still quite dim during the early years.

I was lucky to work with some of the earliest pro video equipment starting in smaller TV stations.  In the early to late 80's some stations still used old equipment as they were transitioning.  We still used two old telecinies, where we broadcast late-night movies from 16mm film.  We had a few Quads (2" tape machines).  The heads recorded lines perpendicular to the movement of tape.  The four heads had to be realigned quite a bit by the engineers or you would see drop-out like spots on the screen.  We also had many 1" reel-to-reel tape decks, which were helical scan (at an angle).  Those were still the norm, but of course, Betacam and later, digital formats took over.  I wanted to keep one of the old 2" AMPEX Quad that the one TV station was going to stop using, but knew there was no space and they were very heavy.  We also had a 2" cartridge system where we had to wrap 2" tape into cassettes designed for commercials.  The concept was to place one tape into one side, and it used a huge vacuum that quickly sucked the tape around the moving heads and played quickly.  Then, while that was playing, the machine would queue up another tape on the other side.  So, the cartridges had to be lined up.  At this time, it was old tech, and not reliable for live playback. (42 year television =>=>> digital media tech geek veteran here...):
Saying that there were "3 electron guns" in color television tubes is a huge inaccuracy. Backward compatibility with black and white television precluded adding more guns, and the solution was even more ingenious. There was still only ONE electron gun in a color TV CRT. What determined the brightness of the RGB pixels was that the single gun (B&W) brightness voltage was secondarily modulated with a carrier frequency of 3.8Mhz. That modulation determined the proportion of signal that excited each of the R, G & B phosphors along the scan line. To keep the pitch of the gun aligned, a brief burst of the 3.8Mhz carrier frequency (the "color burst") was inserted at the beginning of each scan line, just after the synchronizing (horizontal) blanking signal that turned the electron gun off while the magnets reset for the next scan line. The big complication was that Inserting this color reference signal added time to each line / field / frame, though a small enough time period that it was within tolerance of B&W televisions. To make time for the color burst, the 30 frames / 60 fields per second of B&W became 29.97 frames per second (or 59.94 fields). This is why you see the legacy of strange frame and field timing references that have filtered into digital video for backward compatibility. Further, to keep this color information synchronized with the base B&W signals without causing "harmonic ringing", the phase of the carrier was rotated across each pair of frames, so a complete "in phase" loop, defined as a "color frame", takes 4 (interlaced) fields. The final challenge of color TV was trying to count every frame and still stay aligned with real time clocks; the 29.97 fps vs 30 fps difference adds up to about 3 seconds (108 frames) per hour (72 seconds every 24 hours). To solve this last issue, Drop Frame time coding was created, where 2 frames (one "color frame") are skipped ("dropped" from the count) right before the start of every minute, except at the 10 minute marks. Again, the legacy continues to be seen in digital editing programs that will offer Drop Frame time code to count the 29.97 frames (59.94 fields) legacy video timing and produce accurate real world run times. All this TV signal engineering gets quite a bit easier to explain with the visual aid of a waveform / vector scope, an oscilloscope specifically designed for critically examining and motoring the classic NTSC video signal.

The points on an analog TV are not pixels. You can see that clearly from the fact that they are not in a standard grid, they are interlocking. The tricolor points look like pixels only because of specific construction conditions but in fact they have no such function as being pixels.

Even though it pulls towards claiming they are pixels, single electron beam actually hits multiple of these points at once. The reason why the picture remains the right color is because there is a steel mask inside the tube that prevents mixing of the three signals.

Fact is, that the points are interlocking, because the lines electron gun draws on the screen are not even properly aligned with the points. Interlocking is introduced to prevent a chance of the beam drawing in between the points, thus making a dim line.

Should you make the mask fine enough, theoretically you can achieve infinite horizontal resolution as the incoming signal is analog and so has infinite variation. Vertical resolution is determined by the construction of the device.

And all of this happens so fast that a top of the line high speed camera can't capture it all. I mean, nowadays flat screens are an impressive feat of miniaturization and are very practical because there is no need to have a huge depth to allow the electrons to travel and be bended at achievable angles by a magnetic field.

But in the end, it's just a bunch of small lights flicking on and off.
